He also called himself an optimist, and noted that the fatwa issued in Iran in 1989 was pronounced long ago. The interview is due to appear in the magazine on August 18, but Stern released it on Saturday, a day after the attack on Rushdie.
articles.title: Weeks ago, the writer said life now relatively normal

articles.description: in Tehran, some willing to speak to AP offered praise for an attack targeting a writer they believe tarnished the Islamic faith with his 1988 book “The Satanic Verses.” In the streets of Iran’s capital, images of the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini still peer down at passers-by. “I don’t know Salman Rushdie, but I am happy to hear that he was attacked since he insulted Islam,” said Reza Amiri, 27, a deliveryman.
articles.title: Some praise the attacker, others worry of reprisal & further global isolation

articles.description: Four people were killed and nine others injured in a flash flood in southwest China on Saturday, local authorities said. Footage published by Chinese media showed water rising rapidly in a river on the outskirts of Sichuan province's Pengzhou city. The flood comes during a summer of extreme weather in China, with multiple cities including Shanghai recording their hottest days ever during a heatwave in July.
articles.title: Four dead in China flash flood

articles.description: Several regions of China including the major southwestern city of Chongqing baked in temperatures exceeding 40 degrees Celsius (104 Fahrenheit) on Saturday, while the country's national observatory continued its red alert for extreme heat.

articles.description: China's most populous city Shanghai has extended its weekly Covid-19 test requirement and extended free testing until the end of September in a bid to keep the virus in check, authorities announced on Saturday. Citizens without a record of a nucleic acid test from within seven days will be assigned a yellow code on Shanghai's health code system, the official notice said. A yellow code restricts access to some public venues.
articles.title: Shanghai extends weekly Covid testing requirement until end of Sept

articles.description: Salman Rushdie suffered multiple stab wounds, including one to the right side of his neck, and was lying in a pool of blood under his body after he was attacked at an event here on Friday, according to a doctor who helped the Mumbai-born controversial author following the brutal assault. articles.description:
A vial of the oral polio vaccine. | Ezra Acayan/Getty Images
    

  
How a polio case in New York — and genetic evidence of under-the-radar spread — affects US risk and global eradication efforts.
 For the first time in almost a decade, a case of polio was confirmed in the United States. Health officials in New York’s Rockland County discovered the case last month in an unvaccinated 20-year-old, decades after polio was eliminated from the US in 1979. On August 12, New York City health authorities reported that they had detected the polio virus in the local wastewater system, indicating that the virus was likely circulating under the radar in the city.
With the country and public health system already struggling under the weight of Covid-19 and monkeypox, this news comes as an unpleasant s…
articles.title: New York’s polio crisis, explained

articles.description:

He said there is a sense of shared mission around the strategic situation in the world and the importance of asserting a global rules-based order. 

“I think we’re seeing a real rapport being established between Prime Minister Albanese and President Biden,” he told Sky News Australia.

articles.description:
Sky News Political Editor Andrew Clennell says China wants “political compliance” in return for “economic reliance”.

He said there are fears of a future blockade of the Taiwan Strait by China. 

“There were few signs from the ambassador that there would be a reversal anytime soon in terms of trade bans on Australian beef or wine,” Mr Clennell said. 

“It seems the Chinese government wants to hold that over Australia as if to say there are further trade sanctions that can be put in place.”
articles.title: China wants ‘political compliance’ in return for ‘economic reliance’

articles.description:

It's been revealed the FBI has seized files classed as “top secret” during the search of Mr Trump's Mar-a-Lago home.

“Donald Trump’s back in the news, his base is animated, they think he’s been hard done by,” he told Sky News Australia. 

“It’s going to keep him going for some time to come.”

articles.description:

“Every kid needs their mum,” he said. 

“And every mum, you know, is distraught without being able to be with their kids for all those special occasions.”

articles.description:
Cypress College Political Science Professor Peter Mathews says the Democrats “feel” they “finally accomplished something” as the Senate passed inflation reduction legislation. 

Mr Matthews said the Democrats have majority in the Senate and US House of Representatives. 

“If they came out empty-ended … the voters would have punished them in the midterm elections,” he told Sky News Australia. 

“Inflation is a huge problem.”
articles.title: Democrats feel they ‘finally accomplished something’

Call for Papers: Journal of Strategic Security
The Journal of Strategic Security has issued a call for Papers for its upcoming Special Issue on Urban Security. The special issue will look at a range of urban security issues including urban warfare, urban insurgency, urban crime and insecurity, operating in dense urban terrain (DUT), megacities, and subterranean spaces (SubT), and in the Urban-Littoral interface, as well as the protection of the populace.
Papers addressing the full range of violent actions from high intensity crime to civil strife and other situations of violence, non-international armed conflict (NIAC), and large scale combat operations (LSCO) during international arm…

articles.author: noreply@blogger.com (Newsrust)
articles.description:
When the pandemic closings hit the real estate sector, showings were halted, homes were taken off the market and municipal offices that process closing documents were closed.  As a result, in March 2020, almost 18% of purchase contracts in the United States were canceled – although it took only a few months to return to normal levels.
But in 2022, the frequency of canceled transactions started to rise again, reaching almost 15% in June – the highest rate since the peak of the pandemic, according to a recent report by red finwhich represents approximately 60,000 failed home sales across the country.
The likely culprit: rising mortgage interest rates.  The journey between the accepted offer and the closing day can take up to two months or more, and interest rates sometimes change in the meantime.  Buyers can lock in rates for certain periods, but not all do, and even a small increase can stretch monthly payments out of reach and kill a deal.  And the rate increases this year have been substantial.  Consider, for example, that the average rate for a 30-year fixed rate mortgage rose from 3.79% in January to 5.3% in July.  This change would increase a monthly payment approximately $90 for every $100,000 borrowed.


The places with the highest percentage of deals failed in June – including many in the south and southwest – are among the most popular with buyers.  In Las Vegas, just over 27% of trades failed in June, the highest rate of any market, according to Redfin.  Preferred Florida destinations followed, including Lakeland, Florida at just under 27% and Cape Coral, Florida at just under 26%.


This week’s chart shows the US metropolitan markets where the highest share of trades failed in June.

Source Link
articles.title: Other real estate offers fail

Although it hardly needs to be said, inherent in these fundamental rights is the right to be left alone in our lavish resort estates, whose occupants may or may not have fled with classified documents when leaving the White House. .
On Monday, 30 booted cretins from the FBI violated this fundamental principle of a free society when they besieged to the former president that of Donald Trump Mar-a-Lago mega mansion golf resort to search for such materials.  After presenting a warrant signed by a judge, the agents reportedly took away several boxes of documents.
As Trump himself reported, they even broke into his beautiful and very solid safe.  Appare…
articles.title: The FBI raid on Mar-a-Lago is an attack on all Americans

articles.author: noreply@blogger.com (Newsrust)
articles.description:
To hear the voices of older Americans facing high drug costs month after month is to hear fear and worry, anger and stress.  Many say they’re figuring out how to get by, skipping vacations and other niceties they’ve been saving up for.
For Kim Armbruster, 65, who recently retired from a 40-year career as a nurse, cut costs for her medications for diabetes, psoriatic arthritis and Graves’ disease, an autoimmune disease affecting the thyroid , has been a rush since she started receiving Medicare.  in March.
Ms Armbruster, of Cary, Illinois, said she saved extra insulin on prescriptions filled when she had commercial insurance, enough to cut costs before a monthly cap took effect.  But his other conditions caused immense financial pressure.
By June, she had reached Medicare’s threshold for catastrophic coverage after paying more than $7,000 for Enbrel, a drug she takes for arthritis;  Synthroid, which she takes for Graves’ disease;  Eliquis, for atrial fibrillation, insulin and its insulin pump.
“It’s about thinking ahead, looking for alternatives and strategizing for the home budget so that you can take the necessary medications,” she said.  Learning to cope with costs, she added, has been like “a baptism by fire, learning everything I can possibly learn about managing drug costs and staying healthy without complications.”
The drug carousel taken by Mr Spring, the dementia patient who died in April, included sky-high prices for drugs including Eliquis, for heart disease, and Namenda, an Alzheimer’s drug.  Mr. Spring also took an antidepressant and medication to lessen the side effects of Namenda.

Source Link
articles.title: Medicare beneficiaries could find drug cost relief in health bill

articles.author: noreply@blogger.com (Newsrust)
articles.description:
The recent real estate roller coaster is finally heading in a beneficial direction for buyers.
After report on report On the national housing shortage, the tide has finally turned: According to data from last month, active listing inventory across America has grown more than 30% since 2021 — a record growth rate. 
This is according to Realtor.com July Housing Market Reportwhich further found that July marked the third consecutive month of unprecedented inventory growth rates. 
“Nationally, the inventory of homes actively for sale on a typical day in July has increased 30.7% over the past year, the largest increase in inventory in history. data and higher than last month’s growth rate of 18.7%, which was itself a record.”, notes the July report. In terms of the number of listings, this means that potential buyers saw 176,000 homes more when researched last month than they would have had in 2021. 
	
The increase in the number of available homes – the first of its kind since September 2019 – is a sign that the housing market “continues to move towards more balance”, with buyers now having more options available to them, analyzes The report. 
“With increased inventory, buyers will have more bargaining power,” Realtor Chief Economist Danielle Hale told Bloomberg, adding that the benefits of the pandemic are now a thing of the past for owners.  “The two years of a strong market tilt in favor of sellers appear to be in the rearview mirror.”
The record trend and breath of relief for buyers, however, coincides with median asking prices that remain breathtaking: In June, the nationwide median list price was $449,000, a 17% increase from 2021 and closest to the highest ever reached.  , reported Bloomberg. 
Rising mortgage rates have also had a significant impact and chilling effect on the market recently.

Source Link
articles.title: U.S. real estate listings rise at record pace as market cools
